articles.headline: Buick Sheds Its Old Fogy Image and Lifts G.M.
articles.snippet: Sales at General Motors rose 1 percent in June despite the crisis over faulty ignitions that has prompted lawsuits and huge product recalls, in large part because of rising Buick sales.
articles.abstract: Sales at General Motors rose 1 percent in June despite the crisis over faulty ignitions that has prompted lawsuits and huge product recalls, in large part because of rising Buick sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: As General Motors teetered on bankruptcy just a few years ago, its venerable Buick division seemed on the brink of extinction. The oldest active automobile brand in North America and a car once known as the “moving couch” for its plush interiors, Buick catered to a population of people over 65. Sales had fallen to just 102,000 vehicles in 2009.

articles.headline: In Gaza, Airstrikes and Economic Stress Make for an Anxious Ramadan
articles.snippet: The conflict aside, the new military-dominated government of Egypt has largely shut the tunnel system that fed the Gazan economy, making this holy month a difficult one.
articles.abstract: The conflict aside, the new military-dominated government of Egypt has largely shut the tunnel system that fed the Gazan economy, making this holy month a difficult one.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — War during Ramadan has a particular tension. It is not just the normal anxiety of airstrikes in a crowded city, no matter how carefully Israel tries to target them. But the holy month of Ramadan falls this year in a particularly hot and humid Gaza July, and observant Muslims are fasting, not even drinking water, until sunset and iftar, the evening meal.

articles.headline: Fertility Clinics Scan for the Strongest Embryo
articles.snippet: Fertility clinics are using new chromosomal tests to help identify embryos that will give a woman the best shot at a successful pregnancy.
articles.abstract: Fertility clinics are using new chromosomal tests to help identify embryos that will give a woman the best shot at a successful pregnancy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Annika Levitt initially resisted the fertility clinic’s suggestion that only one embryo — rather than the usual two or more — be transferred to her uterus because she was too small to risk carrying more than one baby.

articles.headline: U.S. Targets South Korea Over Steel
articles.snippet: In a ruling hailed by American steel makers, the Commerce Department says steel tubes and pipes from eight countries were being dumped on the United States market.
articles.abstract: In a ruling hailed by American steel makers, the Commerce Department says steel tubes and pipes from eight countries were being dumped on the United States market.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Commerce Department declared Friday that South Korean steel companies and those in seven other countries were illegally dumping low-cost steel pipes and tubing into the American construction market and would be subject to additional duties.

articles.headline: Chinese Businessman Is Charged in Plot to Steal U.S. Military Data
articles.snippet: The owner of a Chinese aviation company spent years taking data from Boeing on military aircraft and weapons, the Justice Department said.
articles.abstract: The owner of a Chinese aviation company spent years taking data from Boeing on military aircraft and weapons, the Justice Department said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Chinese businessman in Canada hacked into Boeing’s computers and stole information about United States military aircraft and weapons, the Justice Department said on Friday, describing a corporate espionage case that is unusual for the huge amount of data involved.

articles.headline: Heard the News on George Clooney? This Much Is True: He’s Livid
articles.snippet: The actor’s blistering attack on The Daily Mail and its reporting comes as the paper’s website continues its aggressive expansion in the United States.
articles.abstract: The actor’s blistering attack on The Daily Mail and its reporting comes as the paper’s website continues its aggressive expansion in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: The tabloid headline might read something like this: Sexiest Man Alive Becomes Angriest Man Alive.
articles.byline: By Ravi Somaiya and Christine Haughney

articles.headline: Kerry Brokers a Deal to Audit All Afghan Votes
articles.snippet: Afghanistan will conduct an audit of the eight million votes cast in a runoff for the recent presidential election, Secretary of State John Kerry said on Saturday.
articles.abstract: Afghanistan will conduct an audit of the eight million votes cast in a runoff for the recent presidential election, Secretary of State John Kerry said on Saturday.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — After nearly 12 hours of often tense negotiations, Secretary of State John Kerry announced Saturday that Afghanistan would audit all eight million votes cast in a runoff presidential election last month as part of a deal to end a tense power struggle between the top two candidates.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: Biggest Scorer in World Cup? Maybe Univision
articles.snippet: The huge exposure Univision received from the World Cup showed how the growth of America’s Hispanic population has reshaped the media landscape.
articles.abstract: The huge exposure Univision received from the World Cup showed how the growth of America’s Hispanic population has reshaped the media landscape.
articles.lead_paragraph: Months before the first whistle of the World Cup, Juan Carlos Rodriguez, the president of the sports division of Univision Communications, presented his engineers with a challenge: Could they figure out how to beam its soccer broadcasts into American homes faster than its English-language competitors?

articles.headline: Adept? Yes. Adored? Not Yet.
articles.snippet: Lionel Messi has not won over Argentines the way Diego Maradona did, despite being named world player of the year four times.
articles.abstract: Lionel Messi has not won over Argentines the way Diego Maradona did, despite being named world player of the year four times.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Argentine fans unfurled a banner at a World Cup semifinal match in São Paulo depicting Diego Maradona on one side, Lionel Messi on the other and Pope Francis in the middle.

articles.headline: U.S. and Iraqis Try to Fragment Extremist Group
articles.snippet: Officials are seeking ways to exploit fissures between the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria and groups that allied with it to seize much of northern and western Iraq.
articles.abstract: Officials are seeking ways to exploit fissures between the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria and groups that allied with it to seize much of northern and western Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American and Iraqi officials are seeking ways to exploit emerging fissures between the militant group known as the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, and Iraqi extremist groups that allied with it to seize much of northern and western Iraq over the past month.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: Pastor Led Son’s Gay Wedding, Revealing Fault Line in Church
articles.snippet: Frank Schaefer, like other leaders of United Methodist congregations, had difficult choices to make when his son acknowledged that he is gay.
articles.abstract: Frank Schaefer, like other leaders of United Methodist congregations, had difficult choices to make when his son acknowledged that he is gay.
articles.lead_paragraph: Father and son had always been close, from the moment Tim Schaefer was born, six weeks premature, with blood poisoning, a weak heart and lungs, and a doctor who thought he would not make it through the night.

articles.headline: Flunking Out, at a Price
articles.snippet: In Corinthian Colleges’ downfall, taxpayers and borrowers will again pay for regulatory lapses.
articles.abstract: In Corinthian Colleges’ downfall, taxpayers and borrowers will again pay for regulatory lapses.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the years before the mortgage crisis, financial regulators often looked the other way as banks and other lenders pursued reckless activities that cost investors, taxpayers and borrowers billions of dollars. When trouble hit, these regulators had to scramble to fix the mess that their inertia had helped create.

articles.headline: Republicans Replay 2010 Strategy at State Level
articles.snippet: Flush with money and momentum, Republicans are confident that they can at least maintain the gains they made in governors' races four years ago.
articles.abstract: Flush with money and momentum, Republicans are confident that they can at least maintain the gains they made in governors' races four years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Republican candidates for governor around the country have built an unexpectedly strong position for election this fall, helped by an improving economy, disaffection with President Obama and a national fund-raising machine that is leagues ahead of the opposition.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: ‘South Park’ Marches On in New Places
articles.snippet: A three-year deal will give Hulu exclusive rights to stream the huge back catalog of “South Park,” as well as the current season’s episodes.
articles.abstract: A three-year deal will give Hulu exclusive rights to stream the huge back catalog of “South Park,” as well as the current season’s episodes.
articles.lead_paragraph: While the media moguls in Sun Valley, Idaho, jockeyed for parking spaces for their jets and hunted for havens in a consolidating content world, Trey Parker and Matt Stone, the boy-men behind “South Park,” were in Los Angeles, proving again that if you make content people love — it’s harder than it looks — it doesn’t matter how many paradigms shift.

articles.headline: Reporting Rape, and Wishing She Hadn’t
articles.snippet: A freshman said she was sexually assaulted at Hobart and William Smith Colleges. The school’s handling of the investigation left her wishing she had remained silent.
articles.abstract: A freshman said she was sexually assaulted at Hobart and William Smith Colleges. The school’s handling of the investigation left her wishing she had remained silent.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA, N.Y. — She was 18 years old, a freshman, and had been on campus for just two weeks when one Saturday night last September her friends grew worried because she had been drinking and suddenly disappeared.

articles.headline: Amazon, a Friendly Giant as Long as It’s Fed
articles.snippet: Is resistance to Amazon futile in the book publishing world? Its battle with Hachette has many on edge.
articles.abstract: Is resistance to Amazon futile in the book publishing world? Its battle with Hachette has many on edge.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vincent Zandri hails from the future. He is a novelist from the day after tomorrow, when Amazon has remade the worlds of writing, printing, selling and reading books so thoroughly that there is hardly anything left besides Amazon.

articles.headline: From Benghazi to the Boardroom: The Road to the $7 Billion Citigroup Settlement
articles.snippet: How a raid in Libya and a feat of accounting led Citigroup and the Justice Department to a breakthrough in settlement talks.
articles.abstract: How a raid in Libya and a feat of accounting led Citigroup and the Justice Department to a breakthrough in settlement talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:23 p.m. | The stage was set for another public shaming of a Wall Street bank.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Germans End Long Wait: 24 Years and a Bit Extra
articles.snippet: Mario Götze broke a scoreless tie in the 113th minute to give Germany its fourth World Cup title, consigning Lionel Messi and Argentina to defeat and setting off celebrations in Brazil.
articles.abstract: Mario Götze broke a scoreless tie in the 113th minute to give Germany its fourth World Cup title, consigning Lionel Messi and Argentina to defeat and setting off celebrations in Brazil.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — For years, Brazilians had a phrase they would inevitably utter when things went wrong. “Imagina na Copa,” they said after an endless traffic jam or a construction accident or an ugly rash of violence dominated the news — imagine if this happened during the World Cup. It became a foreboding warning, a pre-emptive sigh at the presumed disasters that lay ahead.

articles.headline: Poor Sanitation in India May Afflict Well-Fed Children With Malnutrition
articles.snippet: Many children in India are exposed to a bacterial brew from human waste that may make it impossible for food alone to cure their malnutrition.
articles.abstract: Many children in India are exposed to a bacterial brew from human waste that may make it impossible for food alone to cure their malnutrition.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHEOHAR DISTRICT, India — He wore thick black eyeliner to ward off the evil eye, but Vivek, a tiny 1-year-old living in a village of mud huts and diminutive people, had nonetheless fallen victim to India’s great scourge of malnutrition.

articles.headline: Companies That Offer Help With Student Loans Are Often Predatory, Officials Say
articles.snippet: The debt settlement industry, already accused of questionable tactics related to mortgages, is finding a gold mine of new clients among those with college loans.
articles.abstract: The debt settlement industry, already accused of questionable tactics related to mortgages, is finding a gold mine of new clients among those with college loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Student loan debt hovers at more than $1 trillion, a threefold surge from a decade ago, and a record number of college students who graduated as the financial system nearly imploded have an average debt load of more than $20,000.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Dirty Tricks, Tea Party Suicide and Rising Mississippi Anger
articles.snippet: The suicide of a Mississippi Tea Party founder who was charged in a plot to photograph Senator Thad Cochran’s ailing wife has deepened the enmity left by a divisive Republican primary.
articles.abstract: The suicide of a Mississippi Tea Party founder who was charged in a plot to photograph Senator Thad Cochran’s ailing wife has deepened the enmity left by a divisive Republican primary.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — Mark Mayfield, one of the founders of the Mississippi Tea Party, had lost his political appetite.

articles.headline: Success for Brazil, Just Not on the Field
articles.snippet: Its team suffered a humiliating semifinal defeat, but Brazil is taking comfort in its success as host of the World Cup and in its archrival Argentina’s loss in the final.
articles.abstract: Its team suffered a humiliating semifinal defeat, but Brazil is taking comfort in its success as host of the World Cup and in its archrival Argentina’s loss in the final.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — When Mario Götze settled a crossing pass with his chest and volleyed a goal that won the World Cup, German fans roared in ecstatic release. Those from Brazil were nearly as delirious, even if it was out of relief as much as celebration.

articles.headline: After Lapses, C.D.C. Admits a Lax Culture at Labs
articles.snippet: Recent revelations of safety breaches in the handling of dangerous microbes have created a crisis of faith at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
articles.abstract: Recent revelations of safety breaches in the handling of dangerous microbes have created a crisis of faith at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the head of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, spent much of Wednesday completing a report that would let the public see, in embarrassing detail, how the sloppy handling of anthrax by scientists at its headquarters here had potentially exposed dozens of employees to the deadly bacteria.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Donald G. McNeil Jr

articles.headline: USA Today Goes Viral
articles.snippet: As USA Today’s publisher, the veteran newsman Larry Kramer is hoping America’s largest-circulation newspaper will thrive in a world of social media and mobile platforms.
articles.abstract: As USA Today’s publisher, the veteran newsman Larry Kramer is hoping America’s largest-circulation newspaper will thrive in a world of social media and mobile platforms.
articles.lead_paragraph: TYSONS CORNER, Va. — “Today is a good day to be here because we are starting Social Media Tuesdays,” exclaims Larry Kramer, the publisher of USA Today.

articles.headline: U.S. Sees Risks in Assisting a Compromised Iraqi Force
articles.snippet: A classified report says that many units are deeply infiltrated by either Sunni extremist informants or Shiite personnel backed by Iran, according to U.S. officials.
articles.abstract: A classified report says that many units are deeply infiltrated by either Sunni extremist informants or Shiite personnel backed by Iran, according to U.S. officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A classified military assessment of Iraq’s security forces concludes that many units are so deeply infiltrated by either Sunni extremist informants or Shiite personnel backed by Iran that any Americans assigned to advise Baghdad’s forces could face risks to their safety, according to United States officials.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: BitTorrent to Try a Paywall and Crowdfunding
articles.snippet: The site, whose namesake software is often used for illegal file-sharing, is teaming up with film producers and musicians to charge for downloads.
articles.abstract: The site, whose namesake software is often used for illegal file-sharing, is teaming up with film producers and musicians to charge for downloads.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — This might be the latest twist on crowdfunding — or the web equivalent of seeking a ransom.

articles.headline: Afghans to Alter the Government
articles.snippet: Officials are seeking a stronger parliamentary system nearly a decade after the U.S. pushed a Constitution that enshrined near-dictatorial powers for the Afghan president.
articles.abstract: Officials are seeking a stronger parliamentary system nearly a decade after the U.S. pushed a Constitution that enshrined near-dictatorial powers for the Afghan president.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The deal that Secretary of State John Kerry brokered to ease the Afghan election crisis with a sweeping audit of the vote was quietly built on an even more profound reshaping of the entire government system, American and Afghan officials confirmed Sunday: The sides have agreed to gradually create an empowered prime minister post after years of an all-encompassing presidency.

articles.headline: Drug Firms Make Haste to Elude Tax
articles.snippet: AbbVie has succeeded in winning tentative approval to buy the Irish drug maker Shire, and Mylan Laboratories said it would acquire the international generic drug business from Abbott Laboratories.
articles.abstract: AbbVie has succeeded in winning tentative approval to buy the Irish drug maker Shire, and Mylan Laboratories said it would acquire the international generic drug business from Abbott Laboratories.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:42 p.m. | Health care companies, like many big American corporations, have a long list of complaints: regulation, global competition and, chief of all, taxes.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Chad Bray

articles.headline: Citigroup Settles Mortgage Inquiry for $7 Billion
articles.snippet: The deal with the Justice Department involves one of the largest cash penalties ever paid to settle a federal inquiry into a bank suspected of mortgage misdeeds.
articles.abstract: The deal with the Justice Department involves one of the largest cash penalties ever paid to settle a federal inquiry into a bank suspected of mortgage misdeeds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:29 p.m. | The $7 billion deal that Citigroup agreed to strike with the Justice Department involves one of the largest cash penalties ever paid to settle a federal inquiry into a bank suspected of mortgage misdeeds.

articles.headline: Seeking Soccer Respect, Qatar Looked Abroad
articles.snippet: The gulf nation began an ambitious program to identify and train talented boys from Africa as it sought to build its credibility as host of the 2022 World Cup.
articles.abstract: The gulf nation began an ambitious program to identify and train talented boys from Africa as it sought to build its credibility as host of the 2022 World Cup.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — A little more than a decade ago, Andreas Bleicher, then a director of one of Germany’s Olympic training centers, arrived in the tiny gulf nation of Qatar, wooed there by its royal family to help turn the hopeless national soccer program into something worthy of the world’s respect.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder, Sam Borden, Christopher Harress and Jack Williams
